## Test Scenarios
1. Load beads from workspace .beads/ directory
2. Display tasks grouped by status (ready, in_progress, blocked)
3. Priority filtering (0-4 hotkeys)
4. Task details on Enter key
5. Close task from UI

## Testing Requirements (tmux-based)
**Terminal Size**: 120x40 (wide mode with Tasks panel)

\`\`\`bash
# Create test workspace with beads
mkdir -p /tmp/forge-bead-test/.beads
cat > /tmp/forge-bead-test/.beads/fg.jsonl << 'JSONL'
{"id":"fg-001","title":"Test task one","status":"open","priority":0}
{"id":"fg-002","title":"Test task two","status":"in_progress","priority":1}
{"id":"fg-003","title":"Blocked task","status":"open","priority":2,"blocked_by":["fg-001"]}
JSONL

tmux new-session -d -s forge-bead-test -x 120 -y 40
tmux send-keys -t forge-bead-test "cd /tmp/forge-bead-test && forge" C-m
sleep 3
tmux send-keys -t forge-bead-test "t"  # Tasks view
sleep 1

title: Implement advanced health monitoring
description:
## Overview
Comprehensive health monitoring for workers with auto-recovery.

## Health Metrics
1. **Process Health**: PID exists, not zombie
2. **Activity Health**: Last activity within threshold
3. **Memory Health**: RSS below limit (configurable)
4. **Response Health**: Responds to ping within timeout
5. **Task Health**: No stuck tasks > 30 minutes

## Auto-Recovery Actions
1. Warn: Log warning, show yellow indicator
2. Restart: Kill and respawn worker
3. Escalate: Route to different model tier
4. Alert: Send notification (future: Slack/Discord)

## Requirements
1. Create HealthMonitor in forge-worker
2. Implement health check loop (every 30s)
3. Define recovery policies per health metric
4. Track recovery attempts (max 3)
5. Display health status per worker

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Unhealthy workers marked within 60 seconds
- [ ] Auto-restart triggered after 2 failed checks
- [ ] Recovery logged in Activity Log
- [ ] Health indicators color-coded (green/yellow/red)

set -e

rm -rf /tmp/forge-e2e-test

mkdir -p /tmp/forge-e2e-test/.forge/status
mkdir -p /tmp/forge-e2e-test/.forge/logs

{"id":"e2e-001","title":"E2E Test Task","status":"open","priority":0}
JSONL

for size in "80x24" "120x40" "199x55"; do

  # Start session

  tmux send-keys -t "forge-e2e-\$size" "cd /tmp/forge-e2e-test && FORGE_HOME=.forge forge" C-m

    echo "  ✓ Clean exit OK"
  else
    tmux kill-session -t "forge-e2e-\$size"
    echo "  ⚠ Session persisted (may be quit confirmation)"
  fi
  
  echo ""
done

echo "=== E2E Tests Complete ==="

title: Measure and optimize initialization performance
description:
Profile and optimize forge initialization to achieve < 2 second startup.

**Validation Steps:**

1. **Measure baseline performance:**
   time timeout 10 forge --version
   # Should complete instantly
   
   time (forge &
   sleep 5
   pkill forge)
   # Measure startup time

2. **Check timing diagnostics:**
   forge &  # Start in background
   sleep 5  # Wait for initialization
   pkill forge
   
   tail -100 ~/.forge/logs/forge.log.$(date +%Y-%m-%d) | grep '⏱️'
   
   Expected output:
   ⏱️ DataManager::new() started
   ⏱️ StatusWatcher initialized in XXXms
   ⏱️ Tokio runtime created in XXXms
   ⏱️ BeadManager initialized in XXXms
   ⏱️ Cost database initialized in XXXms
   ⏱️ Initial poll_updates() took XXXms
   ⏱️ DataManager::new() completed in XXXms

3. **Identify bottleneck:**
   Find component with highest time
   Common culprits:
   - StatusWatcher initial_scan() - scanning many status files
   - BeadManager.add_default_workspaces() - recursive directory scanning
   - poll_updates() - synchronous tmux discovery (500ms timeout)
   - Cost database - slow disk I/O

4. **Performance targets:**
   - StatusWatcher init: < 100ms
   - BeadManager init: < 50ms  
   - Cost DB init: < 100ms
   - poll_updates: < 500ms
   - **Total: < 1500ms**

5. **Test with various conditions:**
   # Empty status directory
   mv ~/.forge/status ~/.forge/status.bak
   mkdir ~/.forge/status
   time forge --version
   
   # 100 status files
   for i in {1..100}; do
     echo '{}' > ~/.forge/status/worker-$i.json
   done
   time forge --version
   
   # Restore
   rm -rf ~/.forge/status
   mv ~/.forge/status.bak ~/.forge/status

**Optimization Strategies:**

1. **Defer non-critical init:**
   Move expensive operations out of new()
   Initialize on first use or in background thread

2. **Add timeouts:**
   Ensure no operation blocks > 500ms
   Use tokio::time::timeout for async ops

3. **Cache workspace discovery:**
   BeadManager: cache workspace list
   Skip scanning if no FORGE_WORKSPACES env var

4. **Lazy load cost database:**
   Don't open DB until Costs view accessed
   Use connection pool, not blocking open

5. **Async status scanning:**
   StatusWatcher: scan files in background thread
   Show UI immediately, populate data async

**Pass Criteria:**
- ✅ Total startup < 2 seconds
- ✅ No single component > 500ms
- ✅ UI appears within 1 second
- ✅ Performance documented in logs
- ✅ Works with 100+ status files

title: Implement hot-reload configuration system
description:
## Overview
Enable live configuration changes without restarting forge.

## Hot-Reload Targets
1. Theme changes (immediate visual update)
2. Hotkey bindings (immediate)
3. Refresh intervals (within 1 second)
4. Budget thresholds (within 1 second)
5. Model tier mappings (within 5 seconds)

## Requirements
1. Watch ~/.forge/config.yaml for changes
2. Validate config before applying
3. Graceful degradation on invalid config
4. Visual feedback on config reload
5. Preserve app state during reload

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Theme changes visible within 500ms
- [ ] Invalid config shows error, keeps old config
- [ ] Activity log shows "Config reloaded" message
- [ ] No data loss during reload

## Testing Requirements (tmux-based)
**Terminal Size**: 120x40

### Test 1: Theme Hot-Reload
\`\`\`bash
tmux new-session -d -s forge-reload-test -x 120 -y 40
tmux send-keys -t forge-reload-test "forge" C-m
sleep 3
# Change theme in config
sed -i 's/theme: default/theme: cyberpunk/' ~/.forge/config.yaml
sleep 1
# Capture and verify colors changed
tmux capture-pane -t forge-reload-test -pT > /tmp/reload-theme.txt
\`\`\`

### Test 2: Invalid Config Handling
\`\`\`bash
# Corrupt config yaml
echo "invalid: [yaml" >> ~/.forge/config.yaml
sleep 2
# Verify error displayed, app still running
tmux capture-pane -t forge-reload-test -p | grep -i "error\|invalid"
# App should not crash
tmux send-keys -t forge-reload-test "q"
echo $?  # Should be 0 (clean exit when user quits)
\`\`\`

### Test 3: Refresh Interval Change
\`\`\`bash
sed -i 's/refresh_interval_ms: 1000/refresh_interval_ms: 500/' ~/.forge/config.yaml
sleep 2
# Verify faster updates (check timestamp delta)
\`\`\`
